AI.conclusion: The insights on knowledge conflict and the proposed method enhance the understanding of attention head dynamics and provide a robust solution for better integrating contextual and parametric information.
key_contributions: Introduce the phenomenon of superposition in attention heads
Propose JuICE as a practical intervention for knowledge conflicts
Demonstrate significant performance improvements across multiple datasets

title: Reasoning Towards Fairness: Mitigating Bias in Language Models through Reasoning-Guided Fine-Tuning
summary:
Recent advances in large-scale generative language models have shown that
reasoning capabilities can significantly improve model performance across a
variety of tasks. However, the impact of reasoning on a model's ability to
mitigate stereotypical responses remains largely underexplored. In this work,
we investigate the crucial relationship between a model's reasoning ability and
fairness, and ask whether improved reasoning capabilities can mitigate harmful
stereotypical responses, especially those arising due to shallow or flawed
reasoning. We conduct a comprehensive evaluation of multiple open-source LLMs,
and find that larger models with stronger reasoning abilities exhibit
substantially lower stereotypical bias on existing fairness benchmarks.
Building on this insight, we introduce ReGiFT -- Reasoning Guided Fine-Tuning,
a novel approach that extracts structured reasoning traces from advanced
reasoning models and infuses them into models that lack such capabilities. We
use only general-purpose reasoning and do not require any fairness-specific
supervision for bias mitigation. Notably, we see that models fine-tuned using
ReGiFT not only improve fairness relative to their non-reasoning counterparts
but also outperform advanced reasoning models on fairness benchmarks. We also
analyze how variations in the correctness of the reasoning traces and their
length influence model fairness and their overall performance. Our findings
highlight that enhancing reasoning capabilities is an effective,
fairness-agnostic strategy for mitigating stereotypical bias caused by
reasoning flaws.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the relationship between reasoning ability in generative language models and their capacity to mitigate stereotypical bias, proposing a novel fine-tuning method called ReGiFT.
AI.motivation: To investigate how reasoning capabilities in language models impact their fairness and ability to reduce bias in responses, particularly those that are harmful or stereotypical.
AI.method: The authors evaluate various open-source large language models on their reasoning abilities and stereotypical bias, introducing the ReGiFT approach to improve fairness through reasoning traces without specific bias supervision.
AI.result: Larger models with stronger reasoning abilities show significantly lower levels of stereotypical bias. Models fine-tuned with ReGiFT not only improve fairness but also outperform advanced reasoning models in fairness benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Enhancing reasoning capabilities is a promising strategy for reducing bias in language models, demonstrating that improvements in reasoning can lead to better fairness results without specific bias-focused training.
key_contributions: Introduced the ReGiFT approach for infusing reasoning traces into biased models
Demonstrated that improved reasoning abilities can mitigate stereotypical bias
Provided a comprehensive evaluation of open-source LLMs regarding reasoning and fairness

title: Analyzing LLMs' Knowledge Boundary Cognition Across Languages Through the Lens of Internal Representations
summary:
While understanding the knowledge boundaries of LLMs is crucial to prevent
hallucination, research on the knowledge boundaries of LLMs has predominantly
focused on English. In this work, we present the first study to analyze how
LLMs recognize knowledge boundaries across different languages by probing their
internal representations when processing known and unknown questions in
multiple languages. Our empirical studies reveal three key findings: 1) LLMs'
perceptions of knowledge boundaries are encoded in the middle to middle-upper
layers across different languages. 2) Language differences in knowledge
boundary perception follow a linear structure, which motivates our proposal of
a training-free alignment method that effectively transfers knowledge boundary
perception ability across languages, thereby helping reduce hallucination risk
in low-resource languages; 3) Fine-tuning on bilingual question pair
translation further enhances LLMs' recognition of knowledge boundaries across
languages. Given the absence of standard testbeds for cross-lingual knowledge
boundary analysis, we construct a multilingual evaluation suite comprising
three representative types of knowledge boundary data. Our code and datasets
are publicly available at
https://github.com/DAMO-NLP-SG/LLM-Multilingual-Knowledge-Boundaries.

AI.tldr: This study investigates how large language models (LLMs) understand knowledge boundaries across different languages, addressing a gap in previous research focused solely on English.
AI.motivation: Understanding knowledge boundaries of LLMs is crucial to prevent hallucinations, particularly in low-resource languages.
AI.method: The study probes LLMs' internal representations while processing known and unknown questions in multiple languages, analyzing their recognition of knowledge boundaries.
AI.result: The research identifies that LLMs encode knowledge boundaries in specific layers, exhibits a linear structure of language differences, and finds that fine-tuning on bilingual question pair translation improves boundary recognition.
AI.conclusion: The findings lead to a training-free alignment method for enhancing knowledge boundary perception across languages, with a new multilingual evaluation suite introduced for future research.
key_contributions: First study analyzing LLMs' knowledge boundaries across multiple languages.
Proposal of a training-free alignment method to improve knowledge boundary perception.
Creation of a multilingual evaluation suite for cross-lingual knowledge boundary analysis.

title: MEDAL: A Framework for Benchmarking LLMs as Multilingual Open-Domain Chatbots and Dialogue Evaluators
summary:
As the capabilities of chatbots and their underlying LLMs continue to
dramatically improve, evaluating their performance has increasingly become a
major blocker to their further development. A major challenge is the available
benchmarking datasets, which are largely static, outdated, and lacking in
multilingual coverage, limiting their ability to capture subtle linguistic and
cultural variations. This paper introduces MEDAL, an automated multi-agent
framework for generating, evaluating, and curating more representative and
diverse open-domain dialogue evaluation benchmarks. Our approach leverages
several state-of-the-art LLMs to generate user-chatbot multilingual dialogues,
conditioned on varied seed contexts. A strong LLM (GPT-4.1) is then used for a
multidimensional analysis of the performance of the chatbots, uncovering
noticeable cross-lingual performance differences. Guided by this large-scale
evaluation, we curate a new meta-evaluation multilingual benchmark and
human-annotate samples with nuanced quality judgments. This benchmark is then
used to assess the ability of several reasoning and non-reasoning LLMs to act
as evaluators of open-domain dialogues. We find that current LLMs struggle to
detect nuanced issues, particularly those involving empathy and reasoning.

AI.tldr: Introduction of MEDAL, an automated multi-agent framework for improving dialogue evaluation benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of current static and outdated benchmark datasets for chatbot evaluation, which fail to capture linguistic and cultural variations.
AI.method: A multi-agent framework utilizing state-of-the-art LLMs to generate multilingual dialogues and analyze chatbot performance using a strong LLM for cross-lingual comparison.
AI.result: The study uncovers significant cross-lingual performance differences among chatbots and reveals that current LLMs struggle with nuanced evaluations, especially in areas like empathy and reasoning.
AI.conclusion: A new meta-evaluation multilingual benchmark is developed, indicating limitations in LLMs' evaluation capabilities in open-domain dialogue.
key_contributions: Introduction of the MEDAL framework for multi-agent dialogue evaluation
Development of a meta-evaluation multilingual benchmark
Analysis of LLMs' performance on nuanced dialogue evaluation tasks
AI.limitations: Current LLMs are ineffective at detecting nuanced issues in dialogue.
